item.title: Lack of power stalls low-income housing at historic LA hotel
item.description: As more than 90 rooms sit empty, Barclay Hotel owners say years of city inaction to blame.

item.title: Neighbors reunite for Altadena badminton night that’s been going since WWII
item.description: The yearly badminton tradition among neighbors enters its 81st season — the first after the January fires.

item.title: In notoriously dense Koreatown, these tenants are fighting to keep their parking spots
item.description: A state law passed last year allows landlords to replace amenities, such as parking, with accessory dwelling units.

item.title: Federal judge approves duo to monitor LA's compliance with shelter agreement
item.description: The move stems from a long-standing federal legal settlement over the city's response to the homelessness crisis.

item.title: LA County considers reviving COVID-era eviction policy to aid immigrant renters
item.description: As many immigrant families struggle to pay rent, county leaders ask: Is another eviction moratorium the solution?

item.title: California Men’s Service Challenge Calls on 10,000 Men to Serve and Lead in Communities Across California
Cost of marriage licenses to nearly double in Los Angeles County
item.description: Officials cited rising operational costs and other factors for the increase.

item.title: Trump extends TikTok reprieve as deal nears
item.description: While legally questionable, the extension comes just as it appears China and the U.S. finally may have a deal on TikTok's fate.

item.title: Business shutdowns outside the January fire burn zones may have cost Angelenos up to $500 million in lost income
item.description: New data also suggests the Eaton Fire may have landed a harder short-term hit to the local economy than Palisades.

item.title: Which of these 2025 bills will Gavin Newsom sign?
item.description: Newsom has one month to sign or veto bills passed by the state Legislature.

item.title: Menendez brothers lose bid for new trial
item.description: Lyle and Erik Menendez were convicted of first-degree murder in connection with the August 1989 shotgun killings of their parents in their Beverly Hills home.

item.title: LAUSD's unions want new contracts. Here's what's happening now, and what it means for families
item.description: The unions that represent teachers, principals, support staff and construction workers have protested what they say is a lack of progress on new contracts.

item.title: Rare September rain is on the way to Southern California
item.description: It's thanks to Tropical Storm Mario, so also be ready for heat and humidity, and possibly thunder and lightning.

item.title: Kennedy's vaccine panel expected to recommend delaying hepatitis B shot in children
item.description: RFK Jr.'s hand-picked panel of vaccine advisors is expected to vote to delay the hepatitis B shot for newborns. Doctors warn that could fuel a return of a disease virtually eradicated in U.S. kids.

item.title: El California Men’s Service Challenge llama a 10,000 hombres a servir y liderar en comunidades a lo largo del estado
UC evaluating ‘every option’ amid Trump administration demands on UCLA
item.description: The University of California plans to “evaluate every option” to resolve charges of antisemitism brought by the Trump administration against UCLA.

item.title: Trump files $15 billion defamation lawsuit against New York Times
item.description: President Trump filed a $15 billion defamation lawsuit against The New York Times and four of its journalists, accusing them of harming his business and personal reputation.

item.title: FBI director Patel testifies on Capitol Hill amid questions over his leadership
item.description: Kash Patel's appearance in the Senate comes at a delicate time for the director, who is a loyalist of President Donald Trump but has no experience leading an organization like the FBI.

item.title: CSC Interest Form
California’s insurer of last resort would face more scrutiny under bill heading to Newsom’s desk
item.description: The FAIR Plan faces accusations of denying smoke-damage claims and more. Can California lawmakers keep the insurer of last resort accountable?

item.title: Israel has hunted its top enemies around the Middle East. What has it achieved?
item.description: Israel's surprise attack in Qatar on Tuesday targeting Hamas' top political leaders was the latest in a campaign aimed at hunting down Israel's top enemies since the 2023 Hamas-led attack on Israel.

item.title: A UN inquiry accuses Israel of genocide in Gaza, joining a rising chorus
item.description: The report issued Tuesday by experts commissioned by the United Nations' Human Rights Council calls on the international community to end the genocide and take steps to punish those responsible.

item.title: Israel expands its Gaza City ground offensive, pushing thousands of Palestinians out
item.description: The offensive expanded the same day that independent U.N. experts accused Israel of committing genocide in Gaza.

item.title: More California high school seniors applied for college financial aid this year than last
item.description: About 340,000 California students completed a financial aid application, up about 11% over last year.

item.title: Return of humid conditions and triple digit heat for SoCal
item.description: Another monsoonal weather pattern is bringing back chance of thunderstorms and showers

item.title: Proposition 50: Allowing California to use new congressional maps to counter redistricting in Texas
item.description: This measure on the Nov. 4, 2025, California ballot is part of a larger battle for control of the U.S. House of Representatives next year.

item.title: Duplexes are now banned in post-fire Palisades. Here’s why they’re still allowed in Altadena
item.description: L.A. Mayor Karen Bass suspended a state law allowing duplexes, calling more housing unsafe. But in Altadena, L.A. County leaders say these projects could be key for rebuilding.

item.title: Investigation underway into claims LAist unearthed about top LA homeless services officials
item.description: L.A. County investigators have launched a probe into allegations about Va Lecia Adams Kellum and people she hired at the L.A. Homeless Services Authority.

item.title: Long Beach restricts student cellphone use, but gives high schoolers some freedom
item.description: The majority of Long Beach students must turn off and store their electronic devices in their backpacks for the entire school day.

item.title: OC’s standoff with federal government over voter data gets a trial date
item.description: Whether the case will get all the way to trial is unclear, but it's part of a national effort by the Trump administration to obtain unredacted voter data.

item.title: Tens of thousands who died in California state mental hospitals honored on remembrance day
item.description: For decades tens of thousands of of people, many unjustly institutionalized, died in California state hospitals and were buried on site.

item.title: In first interview, Pope Leo XIV takes on billionaires, polarization and war
item.description: Pope Leo XIV reflected on the legacy of Pope Francis and whether he sees himself as more U.S. American or Peruvian.

item.title: Umar Hakim-Dey, a pillar of SoCal’s Muslim community, has died
item.description: He leaves behind a legacy of community service, mentorship and interfaith advocacy.

item.title: Why California backed off again from ambitious AI regulation
item.description: For the third year, the state delayed AI regulation for disclosing and appealing many automated decisions by the state and companies.

item.title: SoCal Edison customers could see a rate hike as soon as next month. What you need to know
item.description: If state regulators approve the increase, ratepayers could see a 10% increase in the coming months.

item.title: As Trump targets national parks that 'disparage Americans,’ advocates warn California history is at stake
item.description: "Restoring Truth and Sanity to American History" orders staff working at all National Park Service locations to remove any content that casts Americans in a negative light.

item.title: Why Trump wants companies to report earnings less frequently
item.description: President Donald Trump would like companies to report their earnings less frequently. Executives have long called for that — but some financial experts worry it would go badly.

item.title: As RFK pushes MAHA, federal cuts shut down California health and nutrition programs
item.description: A judge will decide whether DOGE's health cuts are legal. Local health departments aren't waiting to close clinics, stop programs, cut immunization appointments and lay off workers anyway.

item.title: Officials announce a 'framework' for keeping TikTok online in the US
item.description: U.S. officials have announced a "framework" that would let Chinese-owned short video platform TikTok continue operations in the United States, although the two countries are still working out the details.

item.title: Best things to do this week in LA and SoCal: September 15-18
item.description: Nurses Night at Dodger Stadium, Moth StorySLAM at Los Globos, piñatas at Perrotin Gallery, North Mississippi Allstars at the Troubadour and more of the best things to do this week.

item.title: Last Chance to Register for the 30th Annual River Rally Cleanup and Environmental Expo!
item.description:
All Volunteers Must Pre-Register by Friday, September 19 A reminder that volunteer registration is open for the 30th Annual River Rally Clean-Up and Environmental Expo scheduled for this Saturday, September 20, from 8:00 a.m. to 11:00 a.m. at Wiley Canyon Road, just off of the Via Princessa Bridge and east of Orchard Village Road. This […]

The post Last Chance to Register for the 30th Annual River Rally Cleanup and Environmental Expo! appeared first on City of Santa Clarita.

item.title: It’s your last chance to catch the historic Jeffrey Gibson show at The Broad
item.description: Jeffrey Gibson was the first and only Indigenous artist to represent the U.S. at the Venice Biennale. LA is the only place you can see the work stateside.

item.title: 8 takeaways from a so-so Emmys night
item.description: 'The Studio,' 'The Pitt' and 'Adolescence' took home top prizes on Sunday. And while the wins were deserving, the telecast was meh. Here are a few takeaways from a night that was a real mixed bag.

item.title: The 2028 Olympics will bring a huge security operation to Los Angeles. Critics worry it'll leave a police state
item.description: Homeland Security is overseeing security planning for the Games, which will bring an influx of funding for local law enforcement.

item.title: A former reality star is influencing LA's post-fires rebuilding
item.description: Spencer Pratt is best known from his time on MTV reality show "The Hills." But he's now using his social media presence to weigh in on rebuilding efforts after the L.A. fires.

item.title: Billions spent, miles to go: The story of California’s failure to build high-speed rail
item.description: California’s dream of building a high-speed rail system linking San Francisco and L.A. is a cautionary tale of ambition outpacing funding, planning, and federal support.

item.title: Over-the-Counter Sales of Overdose Reversal Medication Naloxone Decline After Initial Surge
item.description: Sales of the overdose reversal medication naloxone increased after it was made available to the public without a prescription but then dipped quickly in the period following debut of over-the-counter sales.

item.title: Bobby Hart, who co-wrote 'Last Train to Clarksville' and other Monkees hits, dies
item.description: Bobby Hart teamed with Tommy Boyce on such hits as "Last Train to Clarksville" and "I'm Not Your Steppin' Stone."

item.title: Emmys 2025: It was a big night for 'Adolescence,' 'The Studio' and 'The Pitt'
item.description: Noah Wyle, Owen Cooper, Seth Rogen, Jean Smart, Tramell Tillman, Jeff Hiller and Stephen Colbert are all taking home awards tonight. Check out our list of winners.

item.title: Photos: See the red carpet looks at the 2025 Emmy Awards
item.description: Stars including Megan Stalter, Harrison Ford, Selena Gomez and Walton Goggins walked the red carpet on Sunday night ahead of the 77th Emmy Awards.

item.title: The Emmys are tonight. Here's how to watch
item.description: The awards start at 8 p.m. ET on Sunday night, hosted by Nate Bargatze.

item.title: Christmas Tree Lane is going back up in Altadena — a welcome return to tradition post-Eaton Fire
item.description: Months after the Eaton Fire, residents are putting up holiday lights again, starting this weekend.

item.title: California lawmakers deliver major Democratic climate, housing and labor wins to Newsom
item.description: California leaders wrapped this year’s legislative session Saturday afternoon, prolonged by last-minute backroom deals on climate and energy, sparking deep frustration among some lawmakers.

item.title: Lawmakers send Newsom a high-stakes energy overhaul tied to wildfires, utilities and oil
item.description: California lawmakers passed a six-bill climate and energy package extending cap and trade to 2045, expanding the state’s wildfire fund, approving new oil drilling, and opening the door to a regional power market.

item.title: Can a pink dye help control bird poop at the pier? Santa Monica gives it a try
item.description: On Monday, researchers will drop the dye into the water to learn how ocean currents affect pollution. It's the latest step, along with a new task force, to cut bacterial pollution at the popular recreation area.

item.title: La Luz del Mundo leader and his mother indicted on sex trafficking and racketeering charges
item.description: Naasón Joaquín García has been serving a 16-year, 8-month prison sentence in California. His mother was arrested this week in L.A.

item.title: California passes ICE mask ban in closing days of legislative session
item.description: Senate Bills 627 and 805 would ban law enforcement officers from wearing face coverings and require officers to be readily identifiable, respectively.

item.title: Old Orchard Park to Reopen with Upgrades, New Amenities and Art
item.description:
By City Manager Ken Striplin When Santa Clarita incorporated in 1987, Old Orchard Park was already a gathering place where families came together to play, relax and make memories. Nearly four decades later, it remains one of our most beloved parks, and I am proud to share that it has just received a complete transformation […]

The post Old Orchard Park to Reopen with Upgrades, New Amenities and Art appeared first on City of Santa Clarita.

item.title: In last-minute scramble, California lawmakers fail to deliver promised environmental reform
item.description: Senate leaders failed to fix an environmental law rollback for advanced manufacturing, leaving pollution concerns untouched as session ends.

item.title: SB79 heads to Newsom. Bill allows for denser housing around transit hubs
item.description: The bill, among the most controversial housing proposals in recent memory, overcame opposition from local governments, organized labor unions and many legislative Democrats.

item.title: Go inside LA’s old General Hospital before it turns from a spooky Art Deco time capsule into new housing
item.description: Built in 1933, the colossal building known as “The Great Stone Mother” is poised to be the anchor of a city within a city.

item.title: A theatre professor is staging 'listening' sessions for Angelenos to de-stress
item.description: "Listening Hour" sessions are where people can find collective healing by sharing their stories.

item.title: Lead levels in soil exceeded state standards in Eaton Fire burn zone, LA County reports
item.description: The report didn't find high lead levels in the Palisades Fire area. And the county added that “there is no evidence of widespread contamination from fire-related chemicals.”

item.title: California breaks with CDC, cosigns COVID vaccine guidelines from medical groups
item.description: Guidance is in line with the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s recommendations under the Biden Administration.

item.title: California lawmakers pass bill protecting residents’ right to give food, water to unhoused people
item.description: Law says cities can’t enforce laws that stop people and organizations from providing aid for basic survival

item.title: UCLA researchers host science fair to showcase work suspended by the Trump administration
item.description: On Thursday evening, dozens of researchers hosted a science fair at UCLA to demonstrate the long-term impact of frozen grants.

item.title: What happened to the Hollywood Arby’s sign on Sunset Boulevard? Here's what we learned
item.description: The sign, in the shape of a tall 10-gallon hat, disappeared in recent weeks, leaving some Angelenos wondering where it went.

item.title: Newsom strikes climate deal extending California cap and trade, boosting oil production
item.description: Democratic state leaders have proposed a host of energy bills that seek to balance affordability with the state’s ambitious climate goals.

item.title: Santa Clarita Students Win Local, International Awards
item.description:
Sister Cities’ 2025 Young Artists and Authors Showcase Winners Announced Santa Clarita Sister Cities, in partnership with the City of Santa Clarita, is proud to announce the winners of the 2025 Young Artists and Authors Showcase (YAAS). The local winners include: Art (Classic Medium) Art (Digital Medium) Essay/Creative Writing Poetry Music (Original) Photography These outstanding […]

item.title: LA needs more and better parks, report finds. The city wants your input on a new plan
item.description: The 2025 Park Needs Assessment found where L.A. could use new parks and repairs to current ones. The draft plan is open for public comment through mid-October.

item.title: This shop fixes student instruments for free. Now, a music legend is chipping in
item.description: Herb Alpert got his start playing trumpet in L.A.'s public schools. He wants to help make that "magic" possible for students.

item.title: Health care costs are soaring. Blame insurers, drug companies — and your employer
item.description: Some 154 million people in the United States get health care through their employer — and for many, their costs are about to go way up.

item.title: Low birth weight rates rose nearly 50% around Aliso Canyon gas leak, UCLA study finds
item.description: A UCLA study in the journal Science Advances also found a likely increase in miscarriages around the methane leak in the northern San Fernando Valley in 2015.

item.title: Judge pauses Trump policy cutting off schools and shelters to certain immigrants
item.description: A U.S. district judge issued a preliminary injunction, temporarily pausing a series of federal policies aimed at restricting certain immigrants’ access to public benefits and programs.

item.title: The suspect in Charlie Kirk killing has been arrested. Here's what we know
item.description: Analysts and law enforcement authorities are still sifting through evidence and conducting interviews to learn as much as they can about the suspect's beliefs, including bullet casings with messages inscribed on them.

item.title: Historic DTLA restaurant Cole’s French Dip is pushing back closing date
item.description: After a public outpour of support, Cole’s says it's delaying its final closing date to November.

item.title: Is a sitcom set in post-Eaton Fire Altadena in poor taste? Many say yes
item.description: Reactions from Black Altadena residents vary over the development of CBS sitcom from Black-ish creator Kenya Barris and comedian Mike Epps.

item.title: With over 150 problem vacant lots, Long Beach will run an experiment to address them
item.description: After dozens of citations didn’t clean up blighted properties, city officials are offering up to $75,000 for someone to come up with and implement a new idea.

item.title: Cool weather to turn into slow warming this weekend
item.description: Cool today, slightly warmer over next few days.

item.title: Why these two friends are leading the charge to keep physical media alive
item.description: A growing community of collectors are sharing their obscure horror flicks and other physical media.

item.title: An LAX immigration detention stretched from hours into days. Family says it feels like a kidnapping
item.description: Attorneys say federal authorities are seizing any opportunity to hold people for long periods of time.

item.title: 9 out of 10 UC campus police departments fail to comply with state law around protest response
item.description: State law requires public reports on crowd-control weapons. Most UC police agencies ignore it.

item.title: A new art show at Scripps College shows this Mexican artist’s legacy is more than 'apolitical' landscapes
item.description: Alfredo Ramos Martínez’s work has long been seen as apolitical. But this exhibition shows that he was deeply attuned to injustices around him.

item.title: 9 out of 10 UC campus police departments fail to comply with state law around protest response
item.description: State law requires public reports on crowd-control weapons. Most UC police agencies ignore it

item.title: Berbere tacos and egusi kale: breaking down AfriCali cuisine, straight from the source
item.description: Join us on Sept. 18 for our live event with Kiano Moju, author of AfriCali, recipes from my Jikoni.

item.title: Judge issues sharp rebukes of LAPD and federal agents after anti-ICE protests
item.description: The Los Angeles Police Department and Department of Homeland Security are barred from using weapons such as foam bullets and tear gas 'carte blanche' after a federal judge issued preliminary injunctions.

item.title: Rooftop solar installations are falling in LA. Why?
item.description: After rising for years, the number of residential installations in the city of Los Angeles began to drop in 2023. The city isn’t subject to recent changes in state incentives, but other factors may be contributing to the decline.

item.title: State lawmakers pull last-minute effort to reform LA’s ‘mansion tax’
item.description: Saying they need more time to work out fixes, two state senators now plan to re-introduce their bill on L.A.’s "mansion tax" next year.

item.title: LA lags behind on installing cameras to quell speeding on dangerous roads
item.description: The city is running behind its peers throughout the state that are also piloting speed safety cameras.

item.title: After 10 years of black hole science, Stephen Hawking is proven right
item.description: Researchers have spent 10 years improving the massive detectors they use to catch shockwaves from colliding black holes, and now the science is precise enough to test one of Stephen Hawking's key ideas.

item.title: High-speed train from California to Las Vegas tries to slow rising costs
item.description: Brightline West is betting it can build the first true high-speed rail line in the U.S. But the company says costs are rising, despite its best efforts to keep them down.

item.title: Hundreds of South Koreans arrested in a US immigration raid are being sent home
item.description: U.S. immigration authorities are preparing to send more than 300 South Korean workers home on a chartered flight from Atlanta, a week after detaining them for allegedly working illegally.

item.title: Get Ready for a Journey to Santa Clarita’s Past at State of the City
item.description:
By Mayor Bill Miranda Who hasn’t, at some point in childhood, dreamed of being a cowboy? The romance and ruggedness of the Wild West have been etched into our imaginations for more than a century — from the grainy magic of early silent films to modern-day hits like Yellowstone. Throw in unforgettable classics like Tombstone […]

The post Get Ready for a Journey to Santa Clarita’s Past at State of the City appeared first on City of Santa Clarita.

item.title: NPR's next news chief built an international career at CNN
item.description: NPR has promoted Thomas Evans, its editorial review chief, to lead the newsroom through a period of change, following Congress' decision to end federal funding of public media.

item.title: The killing of Charlie Kirk adds to a time of political upheaval and violence
item.description: The killing of conservative activist Charlie Kirk Wednesday at a college in Utah is the latest in a series of politically motivated violent acts just in recent months.

item.title: Best things to do this weekend in Los Angeles and Southern California: September 12-14
item.description: Join the East L.A. Mexican Independence Day Festival, party at Nocturnal Wonderland, check out a historic building tour with the L.A. Conservancy, bring the family to Dino Fest and more.

item.title: US marks 24th anniversary of 9/11 terror attacks
item.description: Many loved ones of the nearly 3,000 people killed will join dignitaries and politicians at commemorations in New York, at the Pentagon and in Shanksville, Pennsylvania.

item.title: This summer's buzziest book is about to be your new streaming obsession, and it all takes place in Fullerton
item.description: We hear from ‘Margo’s Got Money Troubles’ author Rufi Thorpe on the inspiration behind the bestselling book that’s going to be a series starring Elle Fanning, Nicole Kidman and Michelle Pfeiffer

item.title: SoCal to stay relatively cool
item.description: Another cool day is on tap for the region.

item.title: Rate of death by suicide among construction workers is high. Here’s why
item.description: Chronic pain, long hours, dangers on the job, and other stressors leads to a suicide rate that's four times higher than the national average

item.title: Tim Meadows, Kim Kardashian and Ben Kingsley round out the casts of new fall TV shows set in LA
item.description: Step into the fictional Los Angeles of the 2025 fall TV season, where Tim Meadows works at the DMV and Glenn Close and Kim Kardashian are high-powered divorce lawyers.

item.title: Supervisor Janice Hahn wants cell towers on Vincent Thomas Bridge to aid in suicide prevention
item.description: The L.A. County supervisor said people in crisis can’t reach help because of bad cell service in the area.

item.title: LA28 Olympic diving moves to the Rose Bowl in a bid to save millions
item.description: The L.A. City Council approved the venue change Wednesday, which organizers say will save $12 million in infrastructure costs.

item.title: State lawmakers unveil bill that would put new limits on LA’s hotly debated ‘mansion tax’
item.description: Taxes on the sale of some newer apartment buildings would be lowered under a plan by Sacramento lawmakers to partially rein in city Measure ULA.

item.title: First came the wildfire. Then came the scams
item.description: As extreme weather becomes more frequent, so too have post-disaster contractor scams like excessive billing and shoddy repairs.

item.title: LA City Council endorses Proposition 50
item.description: The measure would change congressional boundaries in California so that five Republican seats likely would flip to Democratic.

item.title: Right-wing activist Charlie Kirk fatally shot at speaking event in Utah
item.description: "The Great, and even Legendary, Charlie Kirk, is dead," President Donald Trump wrote in a Truth Social Post. Kirk was shot during an outdoor speaking event at Utah Valley University on Wednesday.

item.title: Improving School Safety: What the Evidence Says
item.description: What are the biggest safety issues facing schools today? What might help schools respond to social media threats more effectively? Do teachers feel secure in their classrooms? RAND experts Pauline Moore and Brian Jackson tackle these questions and more, sharing practical insights from their research on creating safer school environments.

item.title: The rotten egg smell at the Salton Sea isn’t just a nuisance. It can make people sick
item.description: UCLA researchers have found that hydrogen sulfide emissions at the Salton Sea are at elevated levels and can cause serious health effects to those that live near the lake.

item.title: California considers allowing doctors to prescribe abortion drugs anonymously
item.description: If passed, the law would protect doctors from legal risk by letting them omit their names from prescription labels for abortion pills. It would affect the many doctors who use California pharmacies.

item.title: 33 million voters have been run through a Trump administration citizenship check
item.description: Tens of millions of voters have had their information run through the tool — a striking portion of the U.S. public, considering little has been made public about the tool's accuracy or data security.

item.title: California leaders negotiate major policy changes in secret as legislative session ends
item.description: With just days until the legislative session wraps, California’s top Democrats are discussing a series of climate, energy, and transit measures in backrooms. Details are so scant that even veteran lobbyists and advocates say they are confused and frustrated.

item.title: Ancient microbial life could explain minerals detected on Mars, new study finds
item.description: Scientists report that they may have found Martian minerals that on Earth are formed by microbes in oxygen-free, muddy environments. But they say other explanations are possible, too.

item.title: Hollywood stars boycott Israeli film companies in response to Gaza crisis
item.description: Emma Stone, Ava DuVernay, and Gael Garcia Bernal are among more than 2,000 who signed the petition.

item.title: Cozy morning clouds continue amid cooldown
item.description: Temperatures will cool gradually this week.

item.title: How Los Angeles brings stoke and surf to children with disabilities
item.description: Over the past three years, Los Angeles Recreation and Parks has expanded opportunities for youths with disabilities to catch a wave, build confidence and learn water safety.

item.title: The numbers say you most likely know someone affected by ICE sweeps. What you need to know about the data
item.description: One recent study estimates that nearly one in five Angelenos are undocumented or live with an undocumented family member.

item.title: Law enforcement agencies in California have to report how they use weapons during protests. Many don’t
item.description: Recent protests show major gaps in enforcement of California’s existing protest laws.

item.title: Natalie Crawford, Longtime RAND Analyst Who Guided Research on Modernizing Air Force, Dies at 86
item.description: Natalie Crawford, a RAND Corporation analyst and leading authority on U.S. air and space power who worked closely with top Air Force leaders to shape a research agenda focused on the effectiveness and modernization of the service, has died. She was 86 and had worked at RAND for more than 60 years before retiring earlier this year.

item.title: Downtown LA’s historic The Original Pantry Cafe will reopen its doors
item.description: The union representing the restaurant's workers announced Tuesday that The Pantry will welcome back patrons after suddenly shutting down six months ago.

item.title: An Orange County dog voted in multiple elections. Why that matters in bitter redistricting fight
item.description: Proponents of stricter requirements for voter identification point to incidents like this as evidence that it's easy to skirt California’s voting rules.

item.title: Pilot project at Port of LA generates clean energy using the ocean's waves
item.description: At the Port of Los Angeles, the ocean’s waves area creating renewable energy in a pilot project by the company Eco Wave Power.

item.title: Big Bear housing project proposal moves forward despite concerns from bald eagle fans
item.description: The San Bernardino County Board of Supervisors voted Tuesday to approve the Moon Camp project’s tentative tract map and environmental impact report.

item.title: The federal plan for healthier kids includes 128 ideas, but few details
item.description: The Make America Healthy Again Commission is proposing more than 100 moves to address the root causes of childhood chronic disease. Critics say other Trump administration moves contradict the goals.

item.title: Volunteer for the 2025 Make a Difference Day
item.description:
Give Back and Make a Difference! On Saturday, October 25, the City of Santa Clarita invites residents to roll up their sleeves and join their neighbors for Make a Difference Day – an annual tradition of community service that brings people together to give back in meaningful ways.   Whether you help beautify the courtyard […]

item.title: 60 years later, Dodger great Sandy Koufax's perfect game is still amazing
item.description: Tuesday marks 60 years since Sandy Koufax threw a perfect game at Dodger Stadium. The 1-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs is still considered one of the best games in baseball history.

item.title: Enjoyment of science plummeted along with scores on 8th grade national test
item.description: Eighth grade students lost all gains in science since 2009, the first year the test was given.

item.title: Musicians keep leaving Spotify in protest of CEO's defense investments
item.description: In the last few months, bands including Hotline TNT and King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard have pulled music from Spotify in a new wave of artist-led protests against the platform.

item.title: LA Mayor Karen Bass endorses longtime ally Antonio Villaraigosa in California’s governor race
item.description: The two Los Angeles mayors have known each other for more than five decades.

item.title: A Rancho Palos Verdes neighborhood marks one year without internet. Here's how they're getting by
item.description: Cox Communications pulled its services from the area over safety concerns, leaving neighbors on their own to find ways to connect to the internet.

item.title: City of Santa Clarita Invites Residents to Take Part in the 2025 Hiking Challenge
item.description:
Celebrate History and the Great Outdoors at William S. Hart Park! Grab your hiking shoes and get ready to explore Santa Clarita’s 40th park! The City of Santa Clarita is excited to announce the return of the annual Hiking Challenge at William S. Hart Park. This year’s challenge invites residents to complete all seven trails, […]

item.title: Will California extend cap and trade? Legislative negotiations go down to the wire
item.description: Lawmakers, oil industry leaders and environmental justice groups are meeting behind closed doors to try to reach a deal to extend California’s landmark cap-and-trade program.

item.title: ANNUAL CHUMASH INTERTRIBAL POWWOW COMING TO SANTA YNEZ ON OCT. 4-5
item.description: Native American tribes from throughout North America will come together in Santa Ynez to celebrate Indigenous heritage and culture at the Chumash Intertribal Powwow on Saturday, Oct. 4 and Sunday, Oct. 5, as the event is “Celebrating 60 Years.” The two-day gathering, which is the Santa Ynez Band of Chumash Indians’ largest cultural event of the year, features dancing, singing, drumming, arts, crafts and more.

item.title: Santa Clarita Arts Now Accepting Entries for the 2026 Sidewalk Poetry Project
item.description:
Share a Santa Clarita Secret! The City of Santa Clarita is now accepting entries for its 2026 Sidewalk Poetry Project, an initiative that brings poetry into public spaces by stamping original poems into freshly poured concrete sidewalks throughout the City. Entries are due by Sunday, December 14, 2025.  This year’s theme is “Share a Santa […]

The post Santa Clarita Arts Now Accepting Entries for the 2026 Sidewalk Poetry Project appeared first on City of Santa Clarita.

item.title: Revised data show hiring was overstated in US by 911,000 jobs in past year
item.description: The U.S. likely added 900,000 fewer jobs in the 12 months ending in March than had been reported, according to a preliminary Labor Department report.

item.title: SoCal to get a taste of fall weather this week
item.description: Temperatures will cool gradually this week.

item.title: Santa Ana Police Department reports say officers followed the law during anti-ICE protests. Eyewitnesses tell a different story
item.description: California law that sets guardrails on use of force at protests relies on the police to police themselves.

item.title: What taxpayers need to know one year after Orange County workers started the devastating Airport Fire
item.description: With hundreds of claims still pending and the county on the hook for payouts, here’s what we know about the burden facing Orange County taxpayers.

item.title: Toxic waste dumped decades ago has drastically altered life on SoCal's sea floor, study finds
item.description: The waste was likely dumped alongside barrels of DDT discovered in recent years. Its chemical makeup has changed the types of organisms that live on the ocean bottom.

item.title: Construction workers are getting sick with valley fever in Riverside County. Why are cases up?
item.description: Valley fever mostly infects people who spend time outdoors in dusty areas. For Riverside County, that’s primarily been construction workers.

item.title: Why California might preserve in-state tuition rates for community college students who get deported
item.description: A bill in the state Legislature would allow deported community college students to continue their coursework online at in-state rates. DACA recipients who are denied re-entry to the U.S. would also be eligible.

item.title: LA mayor and immigration activists denounce Supreme Court decision on ICE arrests
item.description: The U.S. Supreme Court lifted restrictions on immigration raids in Southern California.

item.title: Big Bear housing project proposal reignites habitat concerns among bald eagle fans
item.description: If approved, the more than 62-acre project would include 50 housing lots and a marina less than a mile from Jackie and Shadow's famous nest overlooking the lake.

item.title: LA's $30 minimum wage boost for tourism workers moves forward after an effort to overturn it fails
item.description: The City Clerk says a referendum to overturn a minimum wage ordinance failed to gather enough valid signatures. The business group behind it is alleging foul play.

item.title: It’s 908 Day: celebrate Long Beach hometown pride with $9.08 discounts and more
item.description: Long Beach: it’s way more than Snoop Dogg and the Queen Mary.

item.title: LA artist Robert Vargas on his new mural and his bid to break a world record
item.description: The city of L.A. declared Sept. 8 as Robert Vargas Day in 2021. Now, the renowned artist shares how his iconic murals come to life.

item.title: ‘Something can be done about this’: New plan aims to stop sex abuse in California schools
item.description: A new bill would give officials more tools to identify and combat sexual abuse and educate students to better identify the most common signs of grooming behavior.

item.title: Best things to do this week in Los Angeles and Southern California: September 8-11
item.description: Pagliacci at POP, Casablanca screens at the Roosevelt, A/VOID at Chromosonic Field, John Cleese in Anaheim and more.

item.title: California Republicans gird for redistricting fight; some see 'extinction level event' if party loses
item.description: Voters will cast ballots in November on Proposition 50, Gov. Gavin Newsom's redistricting measure.

item.title: A $63 million tech hub at Cal State Northridge aims to attract future engineers
item.description: University officials say they’re betting on the center to expose more first-generation college students to artificial intelligence, robotics and more.

item.title: Vicky Tafoya, a key player in the SoCal revival of rockabilly, doo-wop, swing has died
item.description: Tafoya continued to push the '50s and '60s music styles into the modern era.

item.description:

item.title: Before the Queen Mary docked in Long Beach, the legendary ocean liner ruled the Atlantic
item.description: The British passenger ship was popular with luxury travelers for decades, but it was also a distinguished wartime vessel.

item.title: Culver City’s Citizen Public Market is closing
item.description: The food hall announced it will shut its doors in November.

item.title: A Jane Austen Mystery: Perception of Murder at The MAIN
item.description:
Can Jane Austen Solve a Murder Before Someone is Wrongly Accused? ME Main Productions is delighted to present an original Regency-era whodunit, A Jane Austen Mystery: Perception of Murder, at The MAIN! This thrilling new play blends mystery, wit and romance with just the right touch of spooky intrigue. Audiences will be transported to the […]

item.title: The Business of Creativity: 4th Annual Business for Artists Conference Returns to Santa Clarita
item.description:
Did you know that we are only one month away from the 4th Annual Business for Artists Conference? On Saturday, October 4, the Canyon Country Community Center (18410 Sierra Highway) will be transformed into a hub where creativity and business collide. This free, all-day event brings together artists, musicians, filmmakers and creative professionals for a […]

item.title: SECAF visits VSFB; views SDA Tranche 1 satellite ahead of launch
item.description: Secretary of the Air Force Troy Meink visited Vandenberg Space Force Base Aug. 27-28, 2025, to engage with leadership and gain insight into the base’s strategic role in advancing U.S. space capabilities. Upon his arrival, Meink was greeted by U.S. Space Force Lt. Gen. Douglas Schiess, Commander, U.S. Space Forces - Space; and United States Space Command’s Combined Joint Force Space Component Commander, and Col. James T. Horne III, Space Launch Delta 30 commander. The visit included discussions on Vandenberg SFB’s contributions to national security and space operations.

item.title: Dozens of lightning strike fires are burning across California. A warming climate could bring more, according to new study
item.description: When lightning strikes are abundant, so are wildfires — some in remote places across the state. Scientists warn there may be more in the future.

item.title: Why I think Long Beach is the most exciting food city in Southern California right now
item.description: With less to prove than LA, the city is becoming a center of impressive culinary creativity.

item.title: Cellphone emergency alerts aren't foolproof. Could blaring sirens help during the next big fire?
item.description: Emergency alerts can save your life, but January's fires in L.A. highlighted the limits of cellphone warnings.

item.title: A Home for Culture, Connection and Community in Newhall

item.title: An insurance crisis has forced many foster family agencies to close. What will help keep the rest open?
item.description: The county joins the state in offering bailout dollars for surging liability insurance premiums.

item.title: The Getty Center
item.description: The iconic Getty, with its famed art, architecture, and gardens, is one of L.A.'s greatest attractions. Our guide will explore the highlights and show you how to reach it by transit.

item.title: A breakfast club in Griffith Park has been LA's best-kept secret for 100 years
item.description: The club began as a way for the city’s rich and famous to share a meal and have fun.

item.title: How AGI Could Reshape National Security
item.description: How might the emergence of artificial general intelligence (AGI) reshape global security? RAND experts explore the uncertain future of AGI and identify five major security challenges it could bring—from new “wonder weapons” to sweeping shifts in the balance of global power.
